awd_titl_txt: RUI: Adult neurogenesis: precursor cell regulation and replenishment
awd_abstract_narration: Many vertebrate and invertebrate organisms, including humans, retain the ability to make new neurons throughout life and to incorporate these into circuits in the adult brain. This process of adult neurogenesis occurs in the crayfish brain via a system that has many features in common with higher vertebrates, suggesting a common strategy for the generation of new neurons in adult brains. However, neuronal precursor cells in the crayfish brain are spatially separated, allowing studies on specific components of the lineage. This organization and other aspects of the crayfish system provide unique opportunities to explore the sequence of cellular and molecular events leading to the production of adult-born neurons. In the crayfish brain, first-generation precursors (neuronal stem cells) are not self-renewing, but instead are replenished from a source external to their niche. In vitro experiments suggest the hematopoietic (blood-producing) system as one source of these cells. This proposal will, (1) explore the structure and functional regulation of the first-generation neuronal precursor cells; (2) examine the influence of endogenous and environmental agents on the precursor lineage; and (3) probe the attraction mechanisms between blood cells and the niche in real time with time-lapse cell tracking. If a relationship between blood cells and neuronal stem cells is confirmed by these studies, it is anticipated that this project will have profound implications on our understanding of the mechanisms responsible for the development and evolution of the nervous system. The primary impact of these studies will be to define further the origins and function of neuronal stem cells, to promote a re-examination of the relationship between the hematopoietic and nervous systems in an evolutionary context, and to train numerous undergraduate students as the next generation of young neuroscientists.

por.por_cntn:
The over-arching goal of this project was to test specific mechanisms underlying adult neurogenesis, the birth of new neurons in the adult brain. The relative simplicity of the system producing new neurons in the brains of adult crustaceans makes these animals favorable subjects for these studies. In the crayfish Procambarus clarkii, the 1st-generation neural precursor cells reside in a neurogenic niche on the ventral surface of the brain. The niche contains four morphologically distinct cell types. Type I cells are by far the most numerous; these are bipolar cells whose processes form streams along which 2nd-generation neural precursor cells migrate, finally reaching the brain cell clusters where they differentiate. The 1st-generation neural precursors in the niche are not self-renewing, and thus they must be replenished from an extrinsic source. A major goal of this project was to identify the source of these neural precursors. In vitro and in vivo studies have demonstrated that cells originating in the immune system can serve as neural precursor cells. Of the three classes of blood cells (hemocytes) in P. clarkii, semi-granular hemocytes are the circulating cell type that is attracted to the niche, a process that involves serotonin. Adoptive transfers of labeled semi-granular cells have shown that these cells also have the capacity to generate brain cells that express neurotransmitters appropriate for the regions in which they are located. Indirect evidence suggests that these semi-granular cells are released from the anterior proliferation center, one region that comprises the immune system in crayfish. The lineage of cells that produces adult-born neurons is composed of at least three generations of cells that are spatially separated from each other.  Therefore, the influences of agents on each precursor cell generation can be assessed. Serotonin increases the rate of cell division among the second and third generations of neural precursors, but does not affect the 1st-generation cells in the niche. However, the crustacean cytokine astakine, which is expressed in response to serotonin treatment, does increase the rate of the cell cycle among the 1st-generation neural precursors in the niche. Overall, these studies have defined the immune system as the source of neural precursors that replenish the neurogenic niche, that these precursors are of the semi-granular hemocyte type, and that serotonin influences both the attraction of these hemocytes to the niche and the cell cycle of 2nd- and 3rd-generation neural precursors.  These findings have been used as a tool to educate the general public about the value of model systems and the potential for life-long plasticity in the nervous system, through outreach to senior citizens through neuroscience courses in Lexington, Massachusetts and public lectures throughout the U.S. that are organized by Wellesley College Alumnae Clubs. These projects also have included a major training component, and have involved one research associate, two postdoctoral fellows, 10 undergraduate students and one graduate student visiting from the Federal University of Rio de Janiero, Brazil. 

 


Last Modified: 08/12/2016
Modified by: Barbara S Beltz
